posts.title: Survivor Stories of the Lusitania
posts.body:
Imagine you were en route to Europe one hundred years ago aboard the Lusitania. The majestic ship, one of the larger passenger vessels in the world at the time, neared the Irish coastline several days after its May 1 departure from New York. What was it like to experience the tragedy first-hand?

R.M.S. Lusitania, Hit by Torpedos Off Kinsale Head, Ireland
Credit: Library of Congress, Prints and Photographs Division, Washington, D.C.

U.S. Consul at Cork Wesley Frost’s May 9, 1915, telegram provides two intimate snapshots of Lusitania survivors’ harrowing ordeal. Passenger Robert Rankin testified that throughout the morning of May 7, “Lusitania going slow,” and “had been blowing foghorn till about 10a.m.” Rankin noted that around noontime, the ship started “to zigzag course.” Yet, this was not cause for too much alarm. After a quick lunch, Rankin and three companions walked about on deck. At 2:10pm, one of his party spotted what looked like a submarine, a “low black ridge” just off the ship’s starboard bow. “Torpedo left submarine almost instantly,” Rankin stated, and “traveled rapidly toward boat, leaving white tail.”

Below deck, first class passenger Mrs. Jessie Taft Smith heard and felt the torpedo’s impact. In the reading room after lunch, she stated, she “heard noise and ship seemed to lift.” Smith left for her stateroom, though “was told not to hurry as there was no danger.” Thankfully, she was prepared. “Had beforehand got life belt ready in cabin,” she testified. “Now put it on and went upper deck. Steward helped me into boat hanging in davits. Between 40 and 50 people got in, boat was lowered and we pushed off.”

“Telegram from U.S. Consul at Cork (Frost) to the Secretary of State, May 9, 1915”
Credit: Foreign Relations of the United States 1915. Supplement, The World War, (p 386-387)

Read further details of their accounts: “Telegram from U.S. Consul at Cork (Frost) to the Secretary of State, May 9, 1915,” in the Foreign Relations of the United States 1915. Supplement, The World War, (p 386-387) – and check back this fall for release of the volume online at http://history.state.gov.

posts.title: The United States at the World Expos
posts.body:
Official U.S. Participation in BIE-Sanctioned World Expos, 1851-2015
Credit: Office of the Historian via Palladio

The excitement of World Expos, often referred to as World Fairs, has long captured the imagination. While international trade exhibitions attracted attention in the early nineteenth century, the first big universal exposition officially designated as a “World Expo” by the Bureau International des Expositions (BIE), the governing body of world fairs, was held at London’s Crystal Palace in 1851. Since then, the United States has participated in these dazzling showcases around the world as well as at home. 

U.S. diplomats long stressed the benefits that official participation in international expositions provided. It promoted trade and commerce, and developed an overseas market for U.S. products. Exhibitors demonstrated the country’s technological, scientific, and cultural achievements. In the nineteenth century, when republican democracies were rare, an official presence at World Expos helped impart the ideals and values of the United States. Some Americans considered it a duty to support fellow democracies, especially “sister republic” France, via involvement in the Paris Expos of 1878, 1889 (bicentennial of the French Revolution), and 1900.


Official U.S. Participation by Number of Expos per City
Credit: Office of the Historian via Palladio

The Great War changed many things and postwar U.S. participation increasingly focused on engaging audiences. The United States hosted the 1915 Pan-Pacific International Exposition in San Francisco, but did not partake in another official World Exposition until the 1933 Chicago “Century of Progress” Expo. This Depression-era event provided a much-needed diversion for domestic audiences from harsh economic and employment realities. Importantly, it also displayed U.S.-style capitalism and democracy, a poignant counterpoint to the growth of fascism and communism in other parts of the world. The U.S. presence at international expositions during the Cold War reinforced the “American Dream,” a consumer’s paradise and land of abundance. Since the end of the Cold War, partaking in World Expos provides an avenue for international discussion of global challenges and reinforces longstanding bilateral relationships.


Official U.S. Participation, Nodes
Credit: Office of the Historian via Palladio


For Further Reading:

Robert Rydell, World of Fairs, (Chicago: Chicago University Press, 1993); Robert Haddow, Pavilions of Plenty: Exhibiting American Culture Abroad in the 1950s (Washington, D.C.: Smithsonian Institution Press, 1997); Marguerite Cullman, Ninety Dozen Glasses, (New York: W. W. Norton & Company, 1960); Florence Pinot de Villechenon, Les Expositions Universelles, (Paris: Presses Universitaires de France, 1992); William McKinley, “Third Annual Message,” December 5, 1889, online by Gerhard Peters and John T. Woolley, The American Presidency Project; “World Expos,” Bureau International des Expositions.

posts.title: International Reaction to the Assassination of President Lincoln
posts.body:
April 1865 was an extraordinary month in the history of the Civil War. On the 9th, Confederate General Robert E. Lee surrendered to Lieutenant General Ulysses S. Grant at Appomattox Court House, Virginia, effectively ending the war. Just days later, the nation was rocked by the news that President Abraham Lincoln had been assassinated in Washington, D.C.

This 1865 print from Currier and Ives depicts the assassination. (Photo credit: Wikimedia Commons)

The news of Lincoln’s death reverberated around the world and led to an extraordinary publication by the Department of State in 1866. In addition to the usual diplomatic correspondence published in Foreign Relations of the United States (FRUS) volumes, a separate volume consisting entirely of condolences was published. The volume, Appendix to Diplomatic Correspondence of 1865: The Assassination of Abraham Lincoln, Late President of the United States of America, and the Attempted Assassination of William H. Seward, Secretary of State, and Frederick W. Seward, Assistant Secretary, on the Evening of the 14th of April, 1865, collected correspondence from every corner of the globe.

Lincoln was the first U.S. President to be assassinated. Thus, his death was a test for the country and the strength of its constitutional plan of succession. Some countries noted this fact, and their acknowledgement of Andrew Johnson’s presidency demonstrated that his government was viewed as legitimate in the eyes of the world community. The response from China, for example, embodied both regret and reassurance that the transfer of power was perceived as smooth. Prince Kung, Chief Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, wrote on July 8, 1865, that the announcement of Lincoln’s death “inexpressibly shocked and startled me.” Nevertheless, the news that “on the same day the Vice-President succeeded to the position without any disturbance, and the assassin had been arrested, so that the affairs of government were going on quietly as usual” seemed to satisfy the Prince’s worry, and he hoped that these facts would also “alleviate your grief at the event.”

Other governments sent their official expressions of regret and condolence. Frederick Hassaurek, U.S. Minister to Ecuador, reported on May 29 that the Ecuadorian Government had ordered “that all the officers and employés of the republic of Ecuador shall wear mourning for three days, during which time the Ecuadorian flag shall be displayed at half-mast from all the public buildings.” Additionally, Ecuadorian President Gabriel Garcia Moreno wrote to Hassaurek on May 22 that “The fatal news which arrived by yesterday’s mail has produced a profound and painful impression on me. Never should I have through that the noble country of Washington would be humiliated by such a black and horrible crime; nor should I ever have though that Mr. Lincoln would come to such a horrible end, after having served his country which such wisdom and glory under so critical circumstances.”

In the United Kingdom, British Foreign Minister Earl Russell wrote to U.S. Minister Charles Francis Adams on May 1 that Lincoln’s death was a “sad calamity” and recalled that he had already “conveyed to you by letter and in person the deep impression of horror and indignation which so atrocious a crime on the President of the United States had made upon me.” Russell went on to write that “by the command of the Queen, I have directed her Majesty’s minister at Washington to convey to the government of the United States” the condolences of the British government and British people. From Egypt, Agent and Consul General Charles Hale reported on May 5 that “the Pacha of Egypt, has seized the earliest opportunity to express to me the pain with which he has heard the sad tidings of the assassination of the President of the United States, his detestation of the abominable crime, and his sympathy for our country in the grievous loss we have sustained.”

This photograph of Lincoln was taken on March 6, 1865, shortly before he was assassinated. (Photo credit: Wikimedia Commons)

In the first volume of FRUS, Lincoln had urged the United States to recognize Haiti and Liberia, two countries with unique relationships to slavery. The Haitian Revolution at the turn of the nineteenth century terminated slavery in that country, and soon after Liberia was settled by liberated slaves from the United States. In 1862, the United States recognized both countries, and in 1865 both countries reacted to Lincoln’s death. The Liberian proclamation mourned a man who “was not only the ruler of his own people, but a father to millions of a race stricken and oppressed.” Arguing that Lincoln had “died to redeem a nation, a race,” the Liberians predicted that “generations yet unborn shall call him the mighty ruler, the great emancipator, the noble philanthropist.” The Secretary of the Haitian Legation in the United States denounced the assassination as a “horrid crime,“ and noted that the death of Lincoln and the attempt on the life of both Sewards “have thrown the whole United States into consternation and mourning, [and] will everywhere excite the same wail of sorrow and condemnation.”

Perhaps one of the most remarkable parts of the volume comes not from the official expressions of sorrow but the messages sent spontaneously from other groups of citizens all over the globe. FRUS does not usually publish “unofficial,” non-governmental correspondence, but this volume includes a healthy selection of just that type of correspondence. A group of Freemasons in France wrote to President Johnson that they “wish[ed] to express to you their sentiments of admiration, gratitude, and regret for Lincoln, and their profound sympathy for the government of which you are the head. The blood of your martyred magistrate becomes a fecundating dew to give to liberty a new baptism throughout the entire universe.” The residents of Lahaina, in the Hawaiian Islands, passed resolutions in which they “weep together with the republic of America for the murder, the assassination of the great, the good, the liberator Abraham Lincoln, the victim of hell-born treason—himself martyred, yet live his mighty deeds, victory, peace, and the emancipation of those despised, like all of us of the colored races.” A group of workingmen in the Prussian capital of Berlin noted that Lincoln was a laborer’s son and “himself a laborer, he took up the fight for the rights of free labor and carried it to a triumphant termination.” While mourning his death, the laborers noted that “the freedom which has thus been sealed with the blood of one of the noblest men” will ultimately be victorious, and that the U.S. flag will represent “the cause of freedom and civilization” wherever it flies.

This special volume of FRUS documents a remarkable outpouring of grief at the news of Lincoln’s death. Official expressions of sympathy from governments were printed side-by-side with resolutions and proclamations from groups of citizens. One hundred and fifty years after his time in office, Lincoln still looms large as one of our most significant Presidents. The documents in this volume confirm that his stature around the world was already in place at the time of his death.

This special volume of FRUS documents a remarkable outpouring of grief at the news of Lincoln’s death. Official expressions of sympathy from governments were printed side-by-side with resolutions and proclamations from groups of citizens. One hundred and fifty years after his time in office, Lincoln still looms large as one of our most significant Presidents. The documents in this volume confirm that his stature around the world was already in place at the time of his death.

posts.title: Debating FRUS History in the Reagan White House
posts.body:
For the last few years, FRUS historians have worked at the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library in Simi Valley, California to collect documents for volumes covering the 1980s. In March 2014, Josh Botts made his first trip west to conduct research for the national security policy volume for 1981-1984. While he was chatting with the archivists in Simi Valley, Josh mentioned that his previous project had been focused on the history of the Foreign Relations series. One of these archivists, Lisa Jones, asked if he had seen the brief history of FRUS that had been circulated among some of Reagan’s NSC staffers. Josh was immediately intrigued by the idea that White House staffers had cared enough about the series to look into its past. When he took a break from reviewing defense policy files, Josh asked to take a peek at the document she had encountered as she had processed the records.

From the research that Josh had already done in Department of State records, he assumed that the NSC staffers’ interest had been inspired by efforts undertaken by the Historian’s Office in 1984 and 1985 to secure Reagan’s endorsement for a major acceleration initiative. Josh was surprised to discover that this was not the case at all. Instead, in April 1987, NSC Legal Adviser Nicholas Rostow had taken a break from reviewing the negotiating record for the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty to hail “one of the great achievements … of the United States: the publishing history of Foreign Relations of the United States.” Although Rostow got many of the details wrong in the subsequent five-paragraph overview of the evolution of the FRUS series (if only “Dulles and Eden agreed that there was no serious problem with publishing the Yalta and Potsdam records”), he clearly regarded the series as an important manifestation of the government’s obligation to inform the public about its diplomacy.

Rostow’s emailed memorandum elicited a quick rejoinder from NSC Counselor Peter Rodman, who cited the 1949 China White Paper and the 1955 Yalta FRUS volume as examples of instances when “document release has … been used as a political weapon.” Rodman’s rejoinder to Rostow was striking for how vividly he recalled the controversies surrounding the official publication of foreign policy documents in the early years of the Cold War and how directly he applied the lessons of that past to the contemporary challenge of “defending ourselves against an assault by self-serving ex-negotiators plus the Soviets who have been quite expansive in disseminating their own versions of the [ABM] negotiating history.”

posts.title: The Travels of Secretary John Foster Dulles
posts.body:
In his six years of service, Secretary of State John Foster Dulles made over 120 diplomatic trips abroad and visited 46 countries. This map, made with a data visualization tool created by Stanford University’s Humanities + Design laboratory called Palladio, displays the global travels of Secretary Dulles. The size of each circle is proportionate to the number of visits to that location.

Although the majority of his travels took place in Western Europe, Secretary Dulles traveled extensively in the Eastern Hemisphere and made several trips to East and Southeast Asia, frequently visiting Taipei and Manila. He traveled to 21 countries that no previous Secretary of State had visited, including Australia, Iraq, and Turkey.

This map highlights Secretary Dulles’ first extended trip to Asia, during which he visited seven countries in under two weeks. Arriving in Manila on February 21, 1955, he met with President Ramon Magsaysay before proceeding to Bangkok to attend the first meeting of the SEATO Ministerial Council. Secretary Dulles then traveled to Rangoon, Vientiane, Phnom Penh and Saigon to meet with heads of state and senior officials. These meetings marked the first time a Secretary of State had visited Burma, Laos, Cambodia and Vietnam. He returned to Manila on March 1 to attend a conference of the U.S. Chiefs of Mission in East Asia. Secretary Dulles then traveled north to Taipei, where he exchanged instruments of ratification of the Mutual Defense Treaty with the Republic of China. Secretary Dulles’ extensive travels and deep level of personal and political involvement with foreign nations characterized the conduct of U.S. foreign policy during the Eisenhower administration.

This post and its images were created by VSFS intern Michele Vera.

posts.title: On Official Business: Travels of the U.S. Presidents and Secretaries of State
posts.body:
The Office of the Historian maintains this list of official travels made by U.S. Presidents and Secretaries of State abroad. These trips are made for reasons such as to attend international conferences, meet with foreign heads of state, or to advance major policy initiatives; and they represent significant events in the history of U.S. foreign policy. This information can be plotted on a map, but presenting the travels geographically can obscure important facts. For example, here is a map of all travels to the Korean Peninsula listed at history.state.gov mapped with Palladio, a data visualization tool created by Stanford University’s Humanities + Design laboratory. The size of each circle is proportionate to the number of people who visited each locale.

Plotting locations on a map like this shows places that have been visited, but nothing further. Travels to these locations and the individuals who made the trips, however, can also be shown as this network graph.

Despite losing the sense of geography that the map conveyed, displaying this information as a network graph shows how extensively each individual had the opportunity to travel the area. It expresses the trips in spans of time, connecting the travels that occurred within each person’s tenure of office. This is also a good way of showing trips to nations and territories that have been traveled more extensively, such as France.

This chart highlights many travels associated with significant events of the two world wars in France, including Woodrow Wilson’s visits to Paris and Chaumont for the peace conference that ended WWI, FDR’s visit to Algiers in advance of the Yalta Conference, Ronald Reagan’s address to the European Parliament at Strasbourg commemorating the liberation of Europe, and George W. Bush’s Memorial Day address at Colleville-Sur-Mer in 2002.

posts.title: Now Available: Index to Foreign Affairs Documentation in the U.S. Serial Set
posts.body:
Since 1861, the Department of State has released foreign affairs documentation under the rubric of the Foreign Relations of the United States series. Now, the Office of the Historian has expanded its offerings back to 1817 with the publication of an index to foreign relations materials in the U.S. Serial Set. The U.S. Serial Set began publication with the first session of the 15th Congress. The Department of State made a wide range of material available to Congress from 1817 to 1861, and those documents were, in turn, made available to the public via the U.S. Serial Set. This webpage—http://history.state.gov/historicaldocuments/pre-1861/serial-set—provides an index to these publications, prepared by our outstanding VSFS intern Dawn Whitehead. The index entries are organized into five regions (Africa, Asia and the Pacific, Europe, Middle East, and the Americas) and thereunder by country. The list includes some countries which no longer exist as independent states, such as Texas!

John Quincy Adams was Secretary of State when the U.S. Congress began releasing the Serial Set.

Researchers can use the citation in the index to locate the document itself at their local library, which may have the Serial Set in hard copy or subscribe to an electronic database which contains the information. The Office of the Historian is pleased to provide this resource and hopes to continue to expand its pre-1861 offerings in the future.

posts.title: Spotlight on Dr. George Henry Jackson
posts.body:
Happy Birthday George H. Jackson!

The former U.S. Consul was born February 28, 1863, in Natick, Massachusetts. A graduate of Natick High School and Madison University (today known as Colgate University), Jackson received his MD and STB degrees from Yale University in 1892. He served as a medical missionary in the Congo Free State from 1893 until 1895 when ill health forced his return to New Haven, Connecticut. After two years as an assistant instructor in clinical medicine at Yale Medical School, Jackson entered the Consular Service in 1897.

The doctor spent the following 17 years in western France as U.S. Consul at Cognac and La Rochelle. Jackson was one of the few African American consuls in Europe at the time, though efforts to expand consular opportunities were hallmarks of the McKinley, Roosevelt, and Taft administrations. He developed a reputation as a master brandy taster, and received accolades and excellent ratings for his consular work through 1909. Department inspectors in 1907, 1910, and 1912 noted that Jackson was highly regarded within his district. “He is attentive to his duties and his habits are good,” the 1907 report noted. Jackson was “genteel and courteous in all respects,” stated an inspector in 1910. “He is popular with Americans and others.” A Department of State inspector noted in 1912 that Jackson “is himself very light in color.” This was an era when discrimination based on skin color was common throughout the United States. For African Americans, lighter skin color often translated into greater opportunities and acceptance within the majority white U.S. culture. French attitudes towards African Americans at the time were more welcoming, thus why several served at consular posts in France.

The consul, however, fit easily into his French surroundings. He was fluent in the language and served as president of Stade Rochelais, an omnisports club in La Rochelle. From 1902 until 1911, Jackson developed the club’s rugby section and adopted yellow and black as the team’s colors. The consul lived in La Rochelle with his wife Grace Lillie (a Caucasian woman) and five children. After his reassignment in 1908, Jackson commuted each day to Cognac and spent 60-90 minutes each day on a train.

Despite accolades, Jackson’s consular career was prematurely truncated in January 1914 after a scandal threatened to surface and drag him—and the Department—through the mud. According to The New York Age, Jackson’s retirement was anything but voluntary. “The post [at Cognac] has always been regarded as the best position held by a colored man in the Consular Service,” the paper noted.

The Jacksons returned to the United States, but were not forgotten. In August 2014, Stade Rochelais dedicated a new section of stadium seats to Jackson in recognition of his service to the club a century ago.

Please visit Sud Ouest’s August 26, 2014, article on Stade Rochelais’ dedication in honor of Jackson in order to view an image of the former consul. Jackson is standing on the viewer’s far left.

Sources

George Henry Jackson, Official Personnel Folders-Department of State; Record Group 146: Records of the U.S. Civil Service Commission; National Archives, St. Louis, MO; “Historique du drapeau du Stade Rochelais,” Les Vignerons, April 5, 2011; “U.S. Consul is Dismissed,” The New York Age, December 11, 1913, 1.

Today, the Office of the Historian is proud to announce the digital publication of twenty volumes from the Foreign Relations of the United States series. These volumes span the globe during the tumultuous early post-WWII years from 1948 through 1951, when the contours of the Cold War were being drawn. posts.title: The Rogers Act and the Creation of the Foreign Service
posts.body:
For the past several months, we’ve posted brief introductions to many U.S. diplomats serving abroad as the Great War erupted in 1914. We’ve also shared some of the many stories of how these and other U.S. diplomats responded to the unprecedented demands placed upon them by the outbreak of war. While they performed admirably in meeting these burdens, responding to the war strained the existing capacity of the Department of State and what was then known as the Diplomatic Service.


Wilbur J. Carr, a key architect of the Foreign Service, shortly after the passage of the Rogers Act.
U.S. Library of Congress, Prints and Photographic Division, Washington, D.C.

To address this problem after the war ended, Congress debated measures to strengthen and professionalize the nation’s overseas representation. The most contentious issue that arose was whether or not to integrate the Diplomatic Service, which staffed overseas embassies and legations and focused on political matters, and the Consular Service, which operated a much larger number of consulates and concentrated on commercial and civil duties. The Diplomatic Service was dominated by wealthy elites while the Consular Service was more meritocratic. While diplomats held sway within the Department, consular officials had more support in Congress.

The Rogers Act, passed in 1924, embodied the vision of the longtime head of the Consular Service, Wilbur J. Carr. The law unified the Diplomatic and Consular Services into a new, professional Foreign Service and provided for competitive entrance exams, improved training, meritocratic promotion, and retirement benefits. The Foreign Service had a rocky start: tensions between diplomatic and consular officers persisted, the Great Depression imposed austerity during its early years, and it took decades for the institution to reflect America’s diversity. Yet, the creation of the Foreign Service reflected many “lessons learned” during the Great War and professionalized U.S. diplomatic representation.

posts.title: The Christmas Ship Part II: The Gifts That Keeps Giving
posts.body:
“The Christmas Ship” made its first port of call at Falmouth, England on November 27, 1914, where gifts destined for England and Belgium were unloaded. The Jason arrived in Marseille on December 6 then continued on to Genoa, Italy, and Saloniki, Greece through early 1915. That winter, children in the United Kingdom, Belgium, France, Germany, Austria, Serbia, and Russia received these gifts of goodwill. The project was lauded as a heartening gesture from American children to their counterparts abroad due to the scope and scale of donations.


“The vision of the children in Europe whose fathers have been killed in the war”
Printed in The Pittsburgh Press, Sept 20, 1914

Despite U.S. neutrality, Department of State and military officials played a crucial role in the realization of the plan and thus were appreciated by local populations for their cooperation. Acting Secretary of State Robert Lansing sent instructions to overseas posts telling of the ship’s itinerary. His message ended with a subtle yet stern order:

“This generous and beneficent action on behalf of the children of the United States doubtless will bring comfort and pleasure to many households, and the department feels confident you will take pleasure in giving your cooperation in the proper way.”1

At each harbor, a “Santa Claus” presided over presentation of gifts. The man who played this role was John Callan O’Laughlin, journalist for The Chicago Herald and personal friend of Theodore Roosevelt. U.S. consuls or diplomats were also often in attendance. On December 6, U.S. Consul to Marseille Alphonse Gaulin, along with local officials including Prefect Schrameck, greeted the Jason as she arrived into port. Schrameck conveyed the gratitude of all of France in a heartfelt address:

“The action of the American children brings tears to my eyes from a full heart. Representing the French government, and in its name, I welcome you to Marseille and thank you and the donors for their kindly thought and remembrance for us in this crucial hour.”2


Toys offered by the United States, distributed by Madame Poincaré and U.S. Ambassador William Graves Sharp at the Hôtel de Ville [Paris], undated.
Gallica (Bibliotheque National de France)

The packages destined for Germany were delivered in Genoa and received by an official German delegation, which conveyed appreciation to U.S. children. Baron Adolph Lutz, chairman of the delegation, gave an official statement of gratitude. Once the gifts arrived in Munich, the King of Bavaria stated, “It touches every German heart, and is in keeping with what might be expected of your countrymen.”3

The Empress of Russia sent her own letter of gratitude through diplomatic channels and requested her thanks be published in all the participating newspapers. Russian Ambassador to the U.S. George Bakhmeteff shared “her Majesty’s expressions of sincere gratitude to the children donors” directly with James Keeley at the Herald.4

The safe, timely delivery of “Christmas Ship” toys, clothes, and cans of food to the suffering populations was a symbol of U.S. neutrality and humanitarian aid.

  2. Ibid, 369. ↩

posts.title: Mr. Sharp Goes to Bordeaux
posts.body:
Former Ohio Congressman William Graves Sharp was appointed by President Woodrow Wilson to serve as U.S. Ambassador to France in June 1914 but for several reasons did not immediately assume control of the U.S. Embassy in Paris upon his arrival that September. Instead, as a private citizen, Sharp immersed himself in his new environment. He visited the battlefields to better acquaint himself with the war’s realities and learned about the people of France. Sharp finally assumed control of the Embassy at 5, rue de Chaillot on November 28.


U.S. Ambassador to France William Graves Sharp
Gallica (Bibliotheque National de France)

On December 1, he and his son George boarded the night train to Bordeaux, the temporary seat of the French government (September 2 – December 9). The Sharps arrived the following day. On December 3, Sharp lunched with French Foreign Minister Théophile Delcassé and the British, Japanese, and Russian Ambassadors. The next day at 9am, Sharp presented his credentials to President Raymond Poincaré—the first U.S. Ambassador to do so outside of Paris. Sharp paid personal calls upon other diplomat colleagues in Bordeaux and then departed for Paris.

The brief time spent in Bordeaux with Poincaré and Delcassé, the first time that Sharp met either statesman in person, deeply marked the new U.S. Ambassador. “Your President impresses me as a strong and well-poised man, full of reserved strength,” Sharp wrote to French Ambassador to the United States Jean-Jules (JJ) Jusserand on December 12. “Monsieur Delcassé is not only a statesman for whom I have the highest opinion, but, best of all, a man of heart.”1

  1. Letter from William Graves Sharp to J.J. Jusserand, December 12, 1914. (Ministry of Foreign Affairs Archives, Guerre 1914–1918 États-Unis, Novembre–Decembre, Vol. 490). ↩

posts.title: I Am (Finally) Leaving—For Now
posts.body:
On November 28, 1914, nearly four months after their originally planned departure, U.S. Ambassador to France Myron T. Herrick and his wife Carolyn left Paris for the United States. The Herricks were fêted at the Gare des Invalides by a crowd of French officials and U.S. expatriates as they waved farewell.


Gare des Invalides
Wikimedia Commons

Not everyone who wanted to attend could make the send-off ceremony. President Raymond Poincaré, for example, remained with the Government of France in Bordeaux. Herrick, sad to not see the Frenchman again to personally say goodbye, wrote his friend, “be certain that nothing between us will be forgotten.”1

Special Agent John Work Garrett was also unable to leave Bordeaux. Instead, he telegrammed Herrick aboard the Rochambeau, “good luck and bon voyage.”2 The friendship between the two men continued throughout the war and beyond. Garrett later wrote Herrick that “my wife and I often recur to your kindness to us during the early days of the war, and we look forward to a time when it is over and we shall be able to come home again and see you and Mrs. Herrick.”3

Herrick reciprocated the sentiment. In February 1917, he wrote Garrett,

posts.title: Headings Examined: Most Commonly Used FRUS Headings
posts.body: Every document published in the Foreign Relations of the United States (FRUS) series is given a brief document heading that identifies the type of document it is, who sent it (if applicable), and other important information. There is a large variety of document headings used in FRUS volumes because of the diversity of documents each contains. Here, however, is a chart illustrating the most commonly used document headings in the six FRUS volumes for the Carter administration, including: Human Rights and Humanitarian Affairs, Volume II; Foreign Economic Policy, Volume III; Soviet Union, Volume VI; Arab-Israeli Dispute, January 1977–August 1978, Volume VIII; China, Volume XIII; and Cyprus; Turkey; Greece, Volume XXI. It was created using Palladio, an online data visualization tool created by Stanford University’s Humanities + Design laboratory with support from the National Endowment for the Humanities. Researchers who use FRUS will probably not be surprised that “Editorial Note” and “Memorandum of Conversation” are among the most frequently appearing document headings in these six volumes, but note the other heading at the center of the chart with them, used for memoranda from the President’s Assistant for National Security Affairs, Zbigniew Brzezinski, to President Carter. Also appearing on the chart are headings for telegrams to the U.S. Embassies in Egypt and the Soviet Union, telegrams from Secretary of State Cyrus Vance and the U.S. Embassy in the Soviet Union, and telegrams from the Department of State to all diplomatic posts. Visualizing this data illustrates the different types of documents that were used in the formation of U.S. foreign policy during the Carter administration as they are published in the FRUS series.

posts.title: Points of Intersection: FRUS Cross References
posts.body:
Documents published in the Foreign Relations of the United States (FRUS) series are annotated with information to aid understanding of the text. Sometimes annotation will reveal linkages between documents across the series by referencing materials in other FRUS volumes. This chart was created using Palladio, with cross-reference information from documents in the six FRUS volumes that are available at history.state.gov for the Carter administration. They are the darker circles labeled with their FRUS-subseries years and volume numbers:

frus1977–80v02 = Human Rights and Humanitarian Affairs, Volume II

frus1977–80v03 = Foreign Economic Policy, Volume III

frus1977–80v06 = Soviet Union, Volume VI

frus1977–80v08 = Arab-Israeli Dispute, January 1977–August 1978, Volume VIII

frus1977–80v13 = China, Volume XIII

frus1977–80v21 = Cyprus; Turkey; Greece, Volume XXI The lighter-colored circles represent the other FRUS volumes that are referenced by annotation in those six volumes. Notice how many are referenced by more than one volume. Frus1969–76v17 (the Nixon-Ford-subseries volume on China, 1962–1972) and frus1969–76v38p1 (Foundations of Foreign Policy, 1973–1976) are both referenced by the same three Carter-era FRUS volumes: Human Rights and Humanitarian Affairs, Soviet Union, and China. In fact, two of those references found in the Carter-subseries volumes Human Rights and Humanitarian Affairs and Soviet Union contain cross references to the same document in frus1969–76v17: a February 27, 1972 joint statement from the United States and People’s Republic of China. Visualizing this data demonstrates how volumes on different topics are interconnected, and will allow researchers to explore relationships between documents across the FRUS series.

posts.title: Web of Classification: Document Classifications Used in Carter-Era FRUS
posts.body: Most of the documents published in the Foreign Relations of the United States (FRUS) series were once classified. Information about the original classification and handling restrictions for documents in FRUS volumes for the Carter administration is found in the first footnote of each document. This is a chart showing the most commonly occurring original classification and handling restrictions for documents in the six Carter-era FRUS volumes that are available at history.state.gov, including: Human Rights and Humanitarian Affairs, Volume II; Foreign Economic Policy, Volume III; Soviet Union, Volume VI; Arab-Israeli Dispute, January 1977–August 1978, Volume VIII; China, Volume XIII; and Cyprus; Turkey; Greece, Volume XXI. It was created using Palladio, an online data visualization tool created by Stanford University’s Humanities + Design laboratory with support from the National Endowment for the Humanities. The size of each circle is proportionate to the number of documents with the indicated classification or handling restriction. Carter-era FRUS volumes include documents that were originally classified as sensitive, confidential, secret, and top secret. Documents with no classification marking include handwritten notes, draft memoranda, and letters from members of foreign governments. Exdis, nodis, and immediate are handling instructions, and Cherokee is a codeword designation for a special telegraphic channel established for sensitive Department of State messages. Visualizing this data illustrates the ways in which the historically significant documents published in each FRUS volume were previously restricted.

posts.title: The Provenance: Visualizing Where Carter Administration FRUS Documents Come From—Part 2
posts.body: Historians at the U.S. Department of State research Foreign Relations of the United States (FRUS) volumes at different archival repositories. The provenance for documents in FRUS volumes for the Carter administration is found at the beginning of the first footnote of each document. This is a network graph showing the provenance of the documents in the six Carter-era FRUS volumes that are available at history.state.gov, including: Human Rights and Humanitarian Affairs, Volume II; Foreign Economic Policy, Volume III; Soviet Union, Volume VI; Arab-Israeli Dispute, January 1977–August 1978, Volume VIII; China, Volume XIII; and Cyprus; Turkey; Greece, Volume XXI. It was created using Palladio, an online data visualization tool created by Stanford University’s Humanities + Design laboratory with support from the National Endowment for the Humanities. The size of each circle is proportionate to the number of documents with the indicated provenance. All six volumes contain documents held at the Department of State, the Carter Library, and the National Archives. The circle with no label represents FRUS documents that have no provenance in the first footnote, such as editorial notes or documents that remain fully classified. The Washington National Records Center is a repository for documents that are no longer actively used by federal agencies in the Washington, DC area, before they have entered the records retirement process. The volume on Human Rights and Humanitarian Affairs contains two documents from the Walter Mondale Papers at the Minnesota Historical Society, and the volume on China includes one document from the Henry A. Kissinger Papers at the Library of Congress. Visualizing this data illustrates how a FRUS volume is compiled, and demonstrates that FRUS volumes provide relatively easy access to documents from a variety of archives.

posts.title: A Farewell Feast
posts.body:
By mid-November it was clear that the crisis of the war’s early weeks was past and Ambassador to France Myron T. Herrick arranged to hand control of the Embassy over to his successor, William Graves Sharp. Herrick and his wife Carolyn prepared — again — to leave Paris for the United States. The evening of November 27, Embassy France First Secretary Robert Woods Bliss and his wife Mildred hosted a farewell dinner for the Herricks at their apartment (4, rue Henri Moissan).


Scenes from the Bliss apartment at 4, rue Henri Moissan, Paris.
Credit: Harvard University - Harvard University Archives / Papers of Robert Woods Bliss and Mildred Barnes Bliss, ca. 1860-1969. Photograph Album, France, Belgium, World War I, 1913-1914. HUGFP 76.74 Box 4.

The dinner at the Bliss apartment included Mr. and Mrs. Percival Dodge and several other friends, though many canceled due to illness. With a mimosa arrangement as the centerpiece and white violets at the table ends, the Blisses served up sumptuous fare (much of which there is no direct English-language translation for):

Potage (soup), timballes vauhalières, truites meunières (trout), poulardes garnies (hens), vol au vent de maïs (corn), glace à la vanille (vanilla ice cream), and various desserts alongside wines.


Mildred Barnes Bliss’ notes on the farewell dinner for Ambassador and Carolyn Herrick.
Credit: November 27, 1914 Dinner, Bliss Papers. Dinner Book: Dec. 25, 1912-Apr.19, 1915, HUGFP 76.32 Box 1, Harvard University Archives.

posts.title: Settling In: Diplomatic Needs in Bordeaux
posts.body:
Despite the continuous press of work during Fall 1914, U.S. diplomats and consuls in France found time to write home and share eyewitness accounts once the immediate danger and chaos subsided. In Bordeaux, temporary seat of the Government of France, Special Agent to the U.S. Ambassador in France John Work Garrett wrote home as to the difficulties of remaining in contact.

“I am going to begin a letter to you, but I have no idea whether I shall be able to finish it or not, there are so many interruptions every minute that I find it practically impossible to get time enough for anything outside of the absolutely necessary.”1


John Work Garrett’s Letter to Brother Robert of November 21, 1914.
Credit: GAR 19 Box 2.2 Folder 19 Robert Garrett, John Work Garrett Papers, Special Collections, Milton S. Eisenhower Library, The Johns Hopkins University.

The diplomat asked his brother to send magazines, noting that “we are entirely without them here and I long for them,” and also asked about the score of that year’s Princeton-Harvard football game.

“I hope we won,” Garrett wrote, “if for no other reason than because all three of my secretaries are Harvard men and I don’t want them to have an opportunity to gloat over me.”2 (Unfortunately for Garrett, Harvard won, 20-0.)

That fall, secretaries Louis A. Sussdorff Jr., Captain F. H. Pope, and Nicholas Roosevelt, worked with Garrett to represent U.S., German, and Austro-Hungarian interests to the Government of France, visit prisoner of war and internment camps, and fielded requests to obtain information about missing French citizens in Germany and Austria-Hungary.

To view John Work Garrett’s November 21, 1914, letter in full, please click here.

posts.title: The Geography of FRUS: Visualizing Where Carter Administration FRUS Documents Come From—Part 1
posts.body:
The Foreign Relations of the United States (FRUS) series publishes documents related to major U.S. foreign policy decisions, which come from all over the world. This is a map showing the cities of origin for documents in the six FRUS volumes that are available at history.state.gov for the Carter administration. It was created using Palladio, an online data visualization tool created by Stanford University’s Humanities + Design laboratory with support from the National Endowment for the Humanities. Visualizing this data illustrates where U.S. foreign policies are shaped, and how geographical locations are distributed in FRUS volumes. The Carter administration volumes represented here are: Human Rights and Humanitarian Affairs, Volume II; Foreign Economic Policy, Volume III; Soviet Union, Volume VI; Arab-Israeli Dispute, January 1977–August 1978, Volume VIII; China, Volume XIII; and Cyprus; Turkey; Greece, Volume XXI. The size of each circle is proportionate to the number of documents that were generated in that location. Because the FRUS series is chiefly focused on the formation of U.S. foreign policy, it is unsurprising that most FRUS documents originate in Washington, DC. Carter-era FRUS volumes also include documents that originated in New York, a memorandum of conversation from Camp David, a telegram from Honolulu, and a letter to Carter from former president Richard M. Nixon in San Clemente.

The six Carter administration FRUS volumes on history.state.gov also feature clusters of foreign policy documents that originated in Europe, the Middle East, Asia, and South America. This network map, also created using Palladio, illustrates which FRUS volumes contain documents from which cities. In the center of the network are the locations that the most FRUS volumes have in common. The circle with no label represents FRUS documents that have no city of origin, such as editorial notes or letters from members of foreign governments. Future Carter-era FRUS volumes that the Office of the Historian is now preparing for publication will add to the diversity of locations that FRUS documents come from.

Part 2 of this post will focus on the archives and document repositories where Carter administration FRUS documents have been found.
